reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 23, 2024
reviews.reviewText: Great book tom really enjoyed reading the way you described the 1876 campaign and love between will and Morgan heartwarming

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 24, 2024
reviews.reviewText: Very entertaining, I have always thought this of historical fiction. I often think I was born hundred years too late.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 14, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars The novel was addictive.
reviews.reviewText: This story kept me coming back to where I had left off as a piece of literature that could have happened in the old West.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Excellent! Should be on film
reviews.reviewText: likelikeI like the cover of this book. It's made to look.like a dime store novel, quite charming! I love historical fiction set in the late 19th century in the West. Unfortunately, most novels set in that time period really are dime store novels; not authentic to that time period at all.I was hungering for a really good Western, one that was authentic and that I could lose myself in. I noted that the author of "The Captured Girl" is a history professor, and became hopeful that this is the book I was looking for.It did not disappoint! It's an excellent blend of fiction with real life historical events and people, mostly army officers. It's set during the Indian Wars, mostly in the area of Montana and Wyoming territory, though part of the story takes place in New York City.It's an action and adventure story that isn't always easy to read. In it's authenticity it gets violent and bloody. The characters don't get much rest. Children grow up fast.It is the story of strong woman, captured by Indians at age 14. She is assimilated into that culture, then returned along with her young son, to White culture. It also tells the story of a young army lieutenant, raised in wealthy society, who becomes a man in his own right as he carries out his military duties and falls in love with our heroine, the captured girl. All the characters in this book evolve and grow. It's why they will stay with me for quite some time.One of my favorite perks about reading historical fiction is that I learn so much without trying. I especially like reading on a Kindle, because I can easily fact check to separate the fiction from known history and look up words that are leaving our everyday vocabulary.This book would make a great movie or miniseries. I'm surprised it's not more well known. Something that did take away professionalism are the typos and misspellings. They weren't rampant, but they were there. Careless mistakes like different spellings of the characters names, and inaccurate capitalization, along with bad punctuation. There was only one instance where I couldn't make out what the storyteller meant, due to a typo.However, the book was so good that I easily overlooked those mistakes. I really enjoyed this author's writing and will definitely be reading more of his work!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2023
reviews.reviewText: I found it to be less biased than. many other novels about this subject. It portrayed both sides as good and evil. Not just showing the evil on 1 side against all good on the other.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Best book ever read
reviews.reviewText: It holds your attrition and can’t get it out of your head when done reading I love it

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 22, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Admirable female protagonist
reviews.reviewText: The “Captured Girl” proves herself worthy in every way in this depiction of the Indian Wars of 1870-1877. There are some plot turns that defy reality, but overall they blend in to a well told story. I had a little trouble distinguishing who was who at the start of the book, but that improved greatly within a couple of chapters.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 9, 2022
reviews.reviewText: I've always enjoyed reading western novels but this one has to be one of the best. The characters are great and believable. The adventure never stops and you really feel the excitement and anticipation of what the individuals are going through. I feel it was totally believable, having read true stories about white captives. Morgan is a real bad a...s and my new favorite western hero! This is a throw back to the old western movies I watched as a child and, in my opinion, on the same level as the John Wayne classic "The Searchers". I highly recommend.
Book was easy to read and very interesting. I will seek out other books by this author.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on August 30, 2023
reviews.reviewText: Great characters, strong storyline and a sense of realism that drew me in. I was desperate to reach the end of the narrative but at the same time I didn't want it to end.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 6, 2022
reviews.reviewText: Enjoyed reading this book as it paints a good depiction of the wild west, Indian life and brings characters vividly to life. The romance is portrayed in a believable, sensitive way. It is a tale to warm the soul without being too complex, with a satisfactory outcome.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 14, 2021
reviews.reviewText: I recommend reading Morgans captivity before reading this book as it will make some aspects easier to understand . A pretty good story. I have read a number of westerns but this is the first I've read that is by a male author. The difference between male and female writing is noticeable . I quite enjoyed this .

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on March 8, 2021
reviews.reviewText: What an amazing story! It would make such a good mini series. Fiction mixed with a good dose of fact I think. You can't help but feel anger at the way the indians were forced off their land.
